nodes.text: Ergodicity economics (EE) as advanced by Peters and collaborators is pseudoscience because it has produced few falsifiable implications and meets multiple indicators of pseudoscience, so it should be treated with skepticism
Context: Peters et al. claim mainstream economic theory is conceptually flawed and promote 'ergodicity economics' as a clearer, more parsimonious alternative

Method: Consider a two-asset continuous-time portfolio model where risky asset follows geometric Brownian motion dS/S = mu dt + sigma dB, safe asset yield r, investor chooses fixed fraction theta continuously rebalanced, wealth follows geometric Brownian motion and log wealth evolution obtained by Ito's lemma

Claim (EE prescription): EE prescribes maximizing long-run geometric average growth rate, which for the model yields objective mean r + (mu-r)theta - 1/2 sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal portfolio theta_EE = (mu - r)/sigma^2

Claim (EUT prescription): Expected utility theory with CRRA utility yields objective V(theta)= r + (mu-r)theta - 1/2 gamma sigma^2 theta^2 and optimal portfolio theta_EUT = (mu - r)/(gamma sigma^2), gamma is relative risk aversion
Result: In the portfolio model EE and EUT make identical predictions when gamma = 1 (log utility), otherwise EE corresponds only to the special logarithmic utility case

Claim (testability): The portfolio problem provides a principle way to test EE by estimating mu, r, sigma and comparing observed investor portfolios to theta_EE; similarly EUT makes testable predictions up to an unobserved scaling by gamma

Evidence/Claim: EE has not produced substantive, generalizable testable implications beyond restatements of known growth-optimal results (Kelly, Latan√©) and has not solved standard consumption-investment dynamic problems in a way that yields falsifiable predictions
Evidence: Peters and collaborators state broad claims (for example resolving decision theory, game theory, and asset pricing) without presenting concrete testable applications

Evidence: Indicators of problematic scientific practice in Peters' work include vague or exaggerated claims, improper or out-of-context citation, reliance on limited and criticized experimental evidence, lack of engagement with economics peer review, and slow progress in extending the approach

Evidence: Publication and review pattern: Peters lists many papers but relatively few are published in economics journals; several papers remain unpublished working papers, indicating limited review by domain experts

Evidence: Specific problems include citation of critical literature out of context, citation of a single experimental study that has been criticized, and frequent appeals to very old literature without adding novel, testable extensions

Claim (pseudoscience indicators): EE matches several Wikipedia-listed indicators of pseudoscience: (i) vague/exaggerated/un-testable claims, (ii) improper collection or use of evidence, (iii) limited openness to testing by field experts, (iv) apparent absence of progress in producing new testable results, (v) personalization and (vi) misleading language
Limitation: Author states he is not an EE expert and restricts analysis mainly to Peters 2019 paper and related influential works, acknowledging focus may omit other EE contributions
Conclusion: Until EE provides clear, falsifiable implications and engages disciplinary peer review, it should be treated skeptically and not considered a replacement for established economic theory
